quoteFirst: The little fleet of war-dogs sailed northward, and, on September 1st,
quoteTime: about ten o'clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing, the northwest promontory of Scotland was sighted. At the same instant, two large ships bore in sight on the same quarter, and another vessel appeared to windward.

title: Danton: A study

quoteFirst: I made friends with the sexton and used to ring the Curfew, and afterwards strike the day of the month. My enthusiasm was so great that I used to prolong the ringing from
quoteLast: minutes, until the people in the neighbourhood complained, when I had to reduce the time. On Sunday the bells were supposed to go for half an hour before service, from half-past ten to eleven. The performance was divided into certain parts.
title: The Strand Magazine, Vol. 27, No. 161, May 1904
author: Various

quoteFirst: Drank last of chocolate--two pots--for breakfast.  Dried blankets in a sunny spell, and
quoteLast: started.  Coming to point round which we expected to get view of lake ahead--"Like going into a room where there is a Christmas tree," said George.  Narrow channel around point 2 1/2 miles from east end.
title: A Woman's Way Through Unknown Labrador
author: Hubbard, Mina, 1870-1956

quoteTime: about ten o’clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing, a signal gun was fired from the Florida, and both vessels weighed anchor and got under way for the westward. We made but slow work and little progress, both vessels being somewhat out of repair from a month’s neglect, and the standing and running rigging being very much chafed and worn.
title: The Sufferings and Escape of Capt. Chas. H. Brown From an Awful Imprisonment by Chilian Convicts
author: Brown, Charles H., captain of the bark Florida; Appleton, Elizabeth Haven, 1815-1890 [Editor]

quoteTime: About ten o'clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing of a perfect day Sheila left the Double R ranchhouse for a ride to the Two Forks to visit Doubler. This new world into which she had come so hopefully had lately grown very lonesome.
title: The Trail to Yesterday
author: Seltzer, Charles Alden, 1875-1942

quoteFirst: There was no other chance that evening, as the light was getting bad. Two or three days after,
quoteLast: ing, I was going along to the E---- Bothy, about a mile from the lodge, when I saw about twenty hinds and a stag amongst them, and after putting the glass on him, I knew it was the same stag. I at once went back to tell the head stalker, but finding him not at home, I took the rifle.
title: Amid the High Hills
author: Fraser, Hugh, Sir, 1860-1927

quoteFirst: Pilcher weighed about thirteen stone, including her bundle, and a pint medicine-bottle, which latter article she invariably carried in her dexter pocket, filled with a strong tincture of juniper berries, and extract of cloves. This mixture had been prescribed to her for what she called a sinkingness, which afflicted her
quoteLast: , 11 A.M. (dinner), 2 P.M., 3 P.M. 4 P.M. 5 P.M. (tea), 7 P.M., 8 P.M. (supper), 10 P.M., and at uncertain intervals during the night.
title: Punch, or the London Charivari, Volume 1, Complete
author: Various

quoteFirst: Accumulating years, however, and repeated attacks of gout, to which Harvey had long been a martyr, at length asserted their mastery over the declining body, and William Harvey, the great in intellect, the noble in nature, finally ceased to be, on the 3d of June, 1657, in the eightieth year of his age.
quoteTime: About ten o’clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing, as Aubrey tells us, on attempting to speak, he found that he had lost the power of utterance, that, in the language of the vulgar, he had the dead palsy in his tongue. He did not lose his other faculties, however; but knowing that his end was approaching, he sent for his nephews, to each of whom he gave some token of remembrance,--his watch to one, his signet ring to another, and so on.
title:
The Works of William Harvey M.D.
Translated from the Latin with a life of the author
author: Harvey, William, 1578-1657; Willis, Robert, 1799-1878 [Translator]
